postDescription.postDescription:
Instead of spending a lot of time and money shopping for dog treats why not just make them at home?

Nothing beats the homemade version and you know exactly what‚Äôs going into your dog's food instead of all those suspicious by-products.

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about your dog's health from physiology basics to specific issues.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
We all know that love goes through the tummy. That's why I have a simple recipe for you to bake for your pooch.

Ingredients:

  • 200g rice flour
  • 150g carrots
  • 50g oatmeal
  • 50g Gouda cheese
  • 1 small apple
  • 2 tbsp coconut oil
  • some hot water

Preparation:

  1. Grate the carrots, the apple and the cheese.
  2. Dissolve the coconut oil in a little hot water and let it cool.
  3. Mix all ingredients together into a dough.
  4. Roll out the dough, cut out cookies and bake in the preheated oven (180 ¬∞ C) for about 30 minutes.

Knowledge Makes You and Your Dog Happy! Furry Canine Team

node.postTitle: What Treats Can I Give My 8 Week Old Puppy

postDescription.postDescription: If you are a new dog owner, and you just brought your puppy home, you might ask yourself ‚ÄúWhat Treats Can I Give My 8 Week Old Puppy?‚Äù now that you are in charge of his well-being.

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about your dog's health from physiology basics to specific issues.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
We can help. I remember doing a lot of food-based research before and after I got my puppy. I asked the breeder what she was feeding him, and I purchased a little bag of the food. I then started reading into raw feeding, best kibble brands, and what treats I can give the puppy during training.

Doing the research really paid out in term of getting more knowledge about dog food and because puppies depend on our judgment when it comes to their health, so we owe it to them to make researched choices in what kinds of treats we feed them.

So, now that finally, the puppy is here, first things first, someone has to tell the puppy the house rules. Best way to do it is to turn it into a fun game for the puppy and you.

8 Week Old Puppy Food Nutrients

The necessary nutrients for healthy puppy nutrition are:

  • Carbohydrates
  • Fats
  • Proteins
  • Vitamins
  • Minerals
  • Water Carbs, fats, and protein help build tissue, contribute to muscle growth, and they also provide a puppy with the energy he is known for.

Vitamins, minerals, and water help your young puppy maintain the correct amount of red blood cells, and they help him regulate and maintain normal body temperature.

Just like in humans, water will help hydrate the dog‚Äôs tissues and keeps the spine‚Äôs discs healthy.

It is essential and your responsibility to pick out healthy treats for your growing puppy to ensure his growth and overall health. The more robust a dog is, the longer he can stay by your side.

When choosing the best food option for your four-legged friend, always look for the following characteristics:

  • Protein must be the primary ingredient in a puppy‚Äôs food as well as teats. Excellent sources of protein are deboned chicken, duck, beef, or salmon.
  • High-value dog food won‚Äôt have additives like dyes or artificial flavours in them, which can trigger food allergies in your puppy.

8 Week Old Puppy Food Amount

To make sure you give your puppy the correct amount of food, ask your vet about it, as he or she will be able to provide you with the right information about it.

The amount of food your puppy needs to receive per day depends on his breed.

It is essential to know that puppies require high-value food to be able to grow and get the energy they spend running around.

What Treats Can I Give My 8 Week Old Puppy?

So, after all the above theory, what treats can you give your puppy? We are getting there. One more important remark from my side before I reveal the treats secret üôÉ.

Make sure you do not overfeed your puppy. Subtract the amount of treats from the puppy‚Äôs regular meals.

The best treats for a puppy are:

  • cooked and boneless chicken
  • cooked and boneless duck
  • chicken liver
  • beef
  • beef liver
  • beef lungs
  • beef trachea (*)
  • beef bone marrow bones (**)
  • meaty bones (**)
  • dried salmon
  • horse lungs
  • horse meat
  • horse trachea (*)

(*) only past 10 weeks of age (**) alway supervise your dog when you feed him bones

After reading my list, you might think how on earth can you get your hands on all that. Befriend a butcher, or go to your local butcher and ask him or her where you could get those animal parts.

You can get the items fresh and bake-dry them so that you can conserve the treats better.

Treats are, as the name says, a treat. So make sure you give treats when training when you want your puppy to remember that he did something remarkable.

Knowledge Makes You and Your Dog Happy! Furry Canine Team

postDescription.postDescription: Proteins are the most important nutrition for a dog as they build and maintain body tissues, organs, bones, blood, muscles, nails, hair and help build a strong immune system that can prevent diseases.

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about your dog's health from physiology basics to specific issues.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
You may have various reasons to feed your dog protein-rich dog food, but for your dog, not all proteins are the same. Fish and Meat are both protein-rich sources but they both contain different nutrients.

Some dog food brands also add additional carbohydrates to their dog food. Most dogs will digest these carbohydrates good when cooked but proteins and fats are their natural diet.

So how do you know which high-protein dog food to choose for your pooch? Well before we get there it‚Äôs important to understand what sources are rich in proteins, healthy for your dog and why your dog might (might not) need protein-rich food.

What Has The Most Protein?

We first want to tell you a bit about protein-rich sources. The four grouped sources below are the ones with the highest concentration in proteins. In the next section, we have a few of these protein-rich sources but there are more like greek yogurt, broccoli, lentils, etc.

Some of these protein-rich sources will have better nutrients than others, in the list below we have the best sources for your pooch.

  • Eggs: Some dog foods contain egg inside but you can always mix a boiled egg under the food and most dogs will love them.
  • Fish: Some brands sell food that has some source of fish, the most commonly used fish in these foods is salmon because salmon contains a very high omega-3 fatty acid. Omega-3 helps prevent kidney diseases, arthritis, and high cholesterol.
  • Meat: Is the most natural source of proteins for your furry friend. The most common meats you will find in dog food are beef, turkey, chicken, duck, and venison.
  • Cheese: It sounds weird but cheese also contains a lot of proteins. When feeding your dog a cheese-based food it‚Äôs important to watch the amount of fat. Some cheeses contain more fat than others.

Some brands will add multiple protein sources to their food. These sources should be listed first on the ingredients list. Most of the proteins should come from chicken, salmon, beef or any other kind of meat.

As you will see in the next section there are differences in the type of meat used in dog food. In general, it shouldn‚Äôt be a problem which source is used for proteins unless your dog has an allergic reaction, when this happens it‚Äôs important to talk to your vet to figure out which source created the reaction.

Protein-Rich Sources For Dogs

We made a list with some protein-rich sources for your dog. Each protein source has different nutrients as you can see, that is good for your dog‚Äôs health. It‚Äôs important to keep in mind that not every dog is created equally, therefore your dog might need more or fewer proteins.

Hard-Boiled Egg (50 grams)

  • Carbs: 0.6 grams.
  • Fat: 5.3 grams.
  • Protein: 6.3 grams.

Egg also contains Vitamin A, Vitamin B2 (riboflavin), Vitamin B12 (cobalamin), Vitamin B5 (pantothenic acid), Phosphorus: 86mg and Selenium: 15.4 mcg.

Almonds (28 grams)

  • Carbs: 0 grams.
  • Fat: 14 grams.
  • Protein: 6 grams.

Almonds also contain Vitamin E, Manganeseand Magnesium.

Chicken Breast (172 grams)

  • Carbs:0 grams.
  • Fat: 6.2 grams.
  • Protein: 53.4 grams.

Cottage Cheese (226 grams)

  • Carbs: 6.1 grams.
  • Fat: 2.3 grams.
  • Protein: 28 grams.

Cottage Cheese also contains Phosphorus, Sodium, Selenium, Vitamin B12, Riboflavin, Calcium,and Folate.

Skyr (170 grams)

  • Carbs: 7 grams.
  • Fat: 0 grams.
  • Protein: 19 grams.

Skyr also contains Phosphorus, Calcium, Riboflavin, Vitamin B-12, and Potassium.

Broccoli (91 grams)

  • Carbs:6 grams.
  • Fat:0.4 grams.
  • Protein:2.5 grams.

Beef (100 grams)

  • Carbs: 0 grams.
  • Fat: 11.8 grams.
  • Protein: 26.1 grams.

Salmon (124 grams)

  • Carbs:0 grams.
  • Fat:5.5 grams.
  • Protein:31.7 grams.

Salmon also contains Sodium:107 mg and Potassium:513.36 mg.

Turkey (100 grams)

  • Carbs:0 grams.
  • Fat: 3.2 grams.
  • Protein: 29.9 grams.

Turkey also contains Omega-3: 70 mg, Omega-6: 570 mg, Vitamin B3, Vitamin B6, Vitamin B2, Vitamin B5, Vitamin B12, Vitamin B1and Folate.

As you can see some vegetables also contain proteins and are completely safe to feed your dog. Dogs can eat these protein sources, but keep in mind that the dog‚Äôs digestive system is built different and might not extract the nutrients they need from it.

Therefore we recommend to go with a meat-based diet, if you, for some reason, decide to feed your pooch vegetarian it‚Äôs really important for your dog‚Äôs health to check him regularly, muscles, bones, skin, coat, and blood. Your dog might need extra supplements because the vegetarian meal doesn‚Äôt digest and provide enough nutrients.

The information gathered in the table comes from healthline.com if you have a source in mind to feed your dog you can always check their site for nutrition facts about the source.

Does My Dog Benefit From A High Protein Food?

As with humans, dogs that are active need more proteins for better muscle, tissue and organ development. The normal average healthy dog needs 1.7 grams of proteins per 1 kg of body weight. That means a dog that weighs 27 kg should get 45.9 grams of proteins. When your dog is more active it burns more calories meaning you should feed your dog extra proteins and fats to keep his body healthy.

What‚Äôs an active dog you might ask. Mostly active dogs are the ones used in dog sports. We made a list for you to see if your dog belongs to the active dog group or not.

  • Police Dogs
  • Military K9s
  • Search and Rescue Dogs
  • Herding Dogs
  • Guard Dogs
  • Tracking Dogs
  • Hunting Dogs
  • Agility Dogs
  • Canicross Dogs
  • Disc Dogs
  • Pregnant Dogs
  • Nursing Dogs

The list contains some of the most common sports a dog can do, but when your dog goes running / biking with you, your dog might also need more proteins.

If you aren‚Äôt sure if your dog needs extra proteins it‚Äôs always a good idea to ask your veterinarian to test the blood.

Medical Concerns of High-Protein Dog Food

Most dogs will handle a high-protein diet perfectly, but some dogs can better avoid a lot of proteins.

There is a chance your dog might have an allergy for some protein sources, but this doesn‚Äôt mean that your dog has to avoid proteins. Dogs with kidney problems better avoid high protein foods. If you‚Äôre not sure if your dog has any of these medical conditions you should ask your vet to test the blood.

Recent research shows that healthy older dogs need more proteins than healthy younger dogs because their metabolic-rate is slower than that of younger dogs.

Signs that your dog doesn‚Äôt get enough proteins or has an improper protein to calorie ratio may include any or all of the following.

  • Reduced Growth Rate in puppies
  • Anemia
  • Weight Loss
  • Skeletal muscle atrophy
  • Dull unkempt hair coat
  • Anorexia
  • Reproductive problems
  • Persistent unresponsive parasitism or low-grade microbial infection
  • Rapid weight loss after injury or during disease
  • Failure to respond properly to the treatment of injury or disease

If any or all of these signs are visible to your dog call a vet and have him/her checked. Don‚Äôt try to solve this yourself as you might damage your dog‚Äôs health in the process.

What Makes A Good High-Protein Dog Food?

There are no real guidelines that can be used to label high-protein dog food. But the AAFCO published a nutrient requirement that states:

The dietary requirement for protein in healthy adult dogs is satisfied when the dog‚Äôs metabolic need for amino acids and nitrogen is satisfied. Optimal diets for growing puppies should contain a minimum of 22% protein as dry matter (AAFCO guidelines) or 45 g protein/1,000 kcal ME for puppies 4‚Äì14 wk old and 35 g protein/1,000 kcal ME for puppies >14 wk old (NRC guidelines). Adult dogs require a minimum of 18% protein as dry matter (AAFCO guidelines) or ~20 g protein/1,000 kcal of ME required (NRC guidelines).

The AAFCO

This means that dog foods that exceed these levels are high-protein dog foods. But you are not there just yet! Some suggest that high-protein dog food should contain less than 43% carbohydrates and have at least 30% protein.

When reading the labels you will also notice a moisture % in your dog food. This gives you the wrong impression of the actual amount of proteins in the food.

It‚Äôs important to find the dry matter basis (DMB) for the dog food.

To do this you can use the following formula:

Protein % / (100 % ‚Äì moisture %) x 100 = Dry Matter Basis (Protein) % An example would be: 34% / (100% ‚Äì 10%) x 100 = 37.7%

You can use this formula to calculate any DMB% in your dog food, but in this case, we are talking about proteins so we gave the example to calculate the DMB(P).

Knowledge Makes You and Your Dog Happy! Furry Canine Team

node.postTitle: 16 People Foods That Are Not Safe For Dogs To Eat

postDescription.postDescription: If you‚Äôd like to reward your dog with table scraps, make sure that you choose people foods that are safe for your puppy.

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about your dog's health from physiology basics to specific issues.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
You try really hard to keep your pooch on his/her canine diet, but sometimes you just can‚Äôt resist slipping him/her an occasional human food.

Here are the top 16 people foods that you definitely have to avoid feeding your dog.

1. Alcohol

Alcoholic beverages and food products containing alcohol can cause vomiting, diarrhea, decreased coordination, central nervous system depression, difficulty breathing, tremors, abnormal blood acidity, coma, and even death.

Under no circumstances should your dog be given any alcohol.

2. Chocolate, Coffee, and Caffeine

These products all contain substances called methylxanthines, which are found in cacao seeds, the fruit of the plant used to make coffee, and in the nuts of an extract used in some sodas. When ingested by dogs, these ingredients can cause vomiting, diarrhea, panting, excessive thirst and urination, hyperactivity, abnormal heart rhythm, tremors, seizures, and even death.

Note that darker chocolate is more dangerous than milk chocolate. White chocolate has the lowest level of methylxanthines, while baking chocolate contains the highest.

3. Citrus

The stems, leaves, peels, fruit, and seeds of citrus plants contain varying amounts of citric acid, essential oils that can cause irritation and possibly even central nervous system depression if ingested in significant amounts. Small doses, such as eating the fruit, are not likely to present problems beyond minor stomach upset.

4. Coconut, Coconut Water and Coconut Oil

When ingested in small amounts, coconut and coconut-based products are not likely to cause serious harm to your dog. The flesh and milk of fresh coconuts do contain oils that may cause an upset stomach, loose stools or diarrhea.

Coconut water is high in potassium and should not be given to your dog.

5. Grapes and Raisins

These fruits can cause kidney failure thus avoid feeding grapes and raisins to dogs.

6. Macadamia Nuts

Macadamia nuts can cause weakness, depression, vomiting, tremors,and hyperthermia in dogs. Signs usually appear within 12 hours of ingestion and can last approximately 12 to 48 hours.

7. Milk and Dairy

Because dogs do not possess significant amounts of lactase (the enzyme that breaks down lactose in milk), milk and other dairy-based products cause them diarrhea or other digestive problems.

8. Nuts

Nuts, including almonds, pecans, and walnuts, contain high amounts of oils and fats. The fats can cause vomiting and diarrhea, and potentially pancreatitis in dogs.

9. Onions, Garlic, Chives

These vegetables and herbs can cause gastrointestinal irritation and could lead to red blood cell damage.

10. Raw/Undercooked Eggs

Raw eggs can contain bacteria such as Salmonella and E. coli that can be harmful to dogs and humans. Raw eggs contain an enzyme called avidin that decreases the absorption of biotin (a B vitamin), which can lead to skin and coat problems.

11. Salt and Salty Snack Foods

Signs that your dog may have eaten too many salty foods include vomiting, diarrhea, depression, tremors, elevated body temperature, seizures, and even death. As such, we encourage you to avoid feeding salt-heavy snacks like potato chips, pretzels, and salted popcorn to your dog.

12. Xylitol

Xylitol is used as a sweetener in many products, including gum, candy, baked goods, and toothpaste. It can cause insulin release in dogs, which can lead to liver failure.

The increase in insulin leads to hypoglycemia (lowered sugar levels). Initial signs of toxicosis include vomiting, lethargy, and loss of coordination. Signs can progress to seizures. Elevated liver enzymes and liver failure can be seen within a few days.

13. Avocado

Avocados contain a substance called persin, which is toxic to dogs and can cause vomiting and diarrhea.

14. Cherries

Cherry pits contain cyanide, which is poisonous. They can also be a choking hazard or block the intestines if a dog swallows them.

15. Bread dough

While bread is generally safe for dogs, the dough can be very dangerous. The yeast in dough can cause it to keep expanding inside the dog‚Äôs stomach, which can cause bloating and lead to dangerous complications. The yeast also produces ethanol, and this can cause alcohol poisoning.

16. Cinnamon

Although not toxic, large amounts of cinnamon can cause vomiting, diarrhea, and liver disease in dogs.

If you suspect that your dog has ingested dangerous foods, contact your veterinarian immediately.

Knowledge Makes You and Your Dog Happy! Furry Canines Team

node.postTitle: Can Dogs Eat Raw Fish And Is Fish Harmful To Dogs

postDescription.postDescription: Fish is a healthy protein and can carry many nutrients such as Omega-3 fatty acids that are beneficial to a dog‚Äôs diet and has benifits linked to the immune system, anti-inflammatory properties.

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about your dog's health from physiology basics to specific issues.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Can dogs eat fish though? Yes, but before you start feeding your dog everyday fish, read this article first.

Is Fish Good for Dogs?

Fish is a healthy protein and can carry many nutrients that are beneficial to a dog‚Äôs diet. Being rich with Omega-3 fatty acids fish has benefits linked to the immune system, anti-inflammatory properties, as well it helps to heal sore, flaky, damaged or itchy skin.

The real advantage to fish in your dog‚Äôs diet though is its ability to provide many good nutrients without the increased risk of weight gain or a protein overload. It is also welcomed by dogs that can not eat another type of protein due to intolerance.

Is Fish Good for Older Dogs?

Fish is a great way to provide your dog with protein without bringing an extra burden on his digestive system if your older dog developed an intolerance towards red meat.

Best Types of Fish for Dogs

There is a lot of fish in the sea, as the saying goes, but are they all suitable for your dog? With so many fish to choose from, it is better to be safe than sorry. The best types of fish for dogs are the short-lived fish species like salmon, ocean whitefish, lake whitefish, herring, walleye, flounder, and Arctic char.

Risks of Feeding Fish to Dogs

Longer-lived fish species like tuna and swordfish can contain heavy metals like mercury. Mercury builds up over time in the dog‚Äôs system and can lead to heavy metal toxicity. The biggest risk of feeding fish to dogs is the fish bones.

Can Dogs Eat Fish Bones?

Definitely NO. Fishbones are small, brittle and completely dangerous since they can get stuck in the dog‚Äôs mouth, throat, stomach and/or intestines and cause choking or holes in the organ‚Äôs walls leading to injuries or even death.

Can Dogs Eat Raw Fish?

Just like with raw chicken, raw fish can be carrying harmful bacteria like salmonella. This can make you and your dog sick.

How Much Fish Can a Dog Eat?

Plain, cooked, steamed, or grilled fish is fine for dogs to eat in moderation. A balanced meal for your puppy is not made of fish every day.

How Should Fish for Dogs Be Prepared?

There are many ways to cook fish for dogs. Just be sure to cook it thoroughly, without seasoning. Grilling or steaming are both good ways to prepare fish since they don‚Äôt require oil or butter that can add unnecessary calories and fat.

Can Dogs Eat Fish Skin?

Sure! Fish skin, when dried, can be used also as a savory treat for your dog. Check out these Vital Essentials dried skin treats for dogs

Some Awesome features that come with vital essentials dried fish skin treats for dogs are:

  • EASY TO DIGEST WILD ALASKAN SALMON RINGS DOG TREAT: freeze dried, easy open reseable pouch, perfect for at home or on-the-go. Packed with Omega 3 and 6 fatty acids for healthy skin and coat. Our freeze-drying process locks in vital nutrients without cooking the raw meat.
  • SINGLE SOURCE PROTEIN: raw, fresh, whole, wild, Alaskan Salmon providing essentials dogs instinctively crave and love.
  • LIMITED INGREDIENT TREAT: the perfect treat option for training or just being a good dog. Made from pure, raw, freeze-dried, wild Alaskan Salmon, no added hormones, no antibiotics, no fillers, ever!
  • 100 percent USA SOURCED, MADE AND PACKAGED: freeze-dried, not cooked, ensuring a fresh, safe, raw, pet treat that is light-weight, travel or pocket friendly.
  • HEALTH AND VITALITY; give your pet the best promoting their health and vitality; protein builds strong muscles and may reduce the risk of injury.

Check Price On Amazon

postDescription.postDescription: If you‚Äôre sure your pooch needs high-protein food we are going to help you a bit with some research we did on the best 3 brands claiming to have high-protein dog food.

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about your dog's health from physiology basics to specific issues.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
We put a few different foods under a magnifying glass to see which one is the best. How did we come to this conclusion? We looked at ingredients (no artificial flavors, colors, or preservatives), DMB(P), price, made in a country with high quality and safety standards the food is manufactured (USA, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, or Western Europe) and reviews.

As with all reviews, there are people claiming the dog food is bad and harms your dog but this is not always true. As we explained in our article High Protein Dog Food, not every dog is created equally and therefore your dog might get an allergic reaction to the food.

For this reason, we didn‚Äôt weigh the reviews that heavily instead we checked some claims people made about the brand to see if they were true or not. What we found is that people also leave negative reviews when their dog gets an allergic reaction to the food but in our eyes, that‚Äôs not the manufacturer‚Äôs fault. Your dog is just allergic to a particular ingredient and therefore you should watch your dog‚Äôs health.

1. Blue Wilderness Adult Salmon, Natural Adult Dry Dog Food

About Blue Wilderness

Their story begins with Blue, their large and lovable Airedale ‚Äì a true family member in every way possible. Blue‚Äôs struggle with cancer prompted them to take a serious interest in a wide range of pet health issues and inspired them to make a super-premium pet food using only the finest natural ingredients starting with real meat. They worked with a leading holistic veterinarian and animal nutritionist to develop BLUE Life Protection Formula¬Æ for dogs and cats, now the 1-selling natural pet food in America.

The Meat & Protein-Rich Diet Is inspired by the diet of wolves, true omnivores whose endurance is legendary, BLUE Wilderness is a protein-rich, grain-free food that contains more of the delicious meat dogs love.

Details

  • PACKED WITH REAL SALMON: A recipe made to satisfy your dog‚Äôs natural love for meat, this high protein dog food features real salmon to help build and maintain lean muscle mass.
  • GRAIN FREE DOG FOOD: BLUE Wilderness grain-free adult dog food is made with healthy carbohydrates including sweet potatoes and peas to help fuel your adult dog‚Äôs active lifestyle. Plus, it contains omega 3 & 6 fatty acids to support skin and coat health.
  • WITH LIFESOURCE BITS: This formula contains BLUE‚Äôs exclusive LifeSource Bits ‚Äì a precise blend of antioxidants, vitamins, and minerals carefully selected by holistic veterinarians and animal nutritionists to support immune system health, life stage requirements, and a healthy oxidative balance.
  • NATURAL DOG FOOD: BLUE dry dog food is formulated for the health and well-being of your dog and features the finest natural ingredients enhanced with vitamins and minerals. It never contains chicken (or poultry) by-product meals, corn, wheat, soy, artificial flavors or preservatives.

Features

Ingredients

Deboned Salmon, Chicken Meal (source of Glucosamine), Peas, Pea Protein, Menhaden Fish Meal (source of Omega 3 Fatty Acids), Tapioca Starch, Dried Tomato Pomace, Pea Starch, Chicken Fat (preserved with Mixed Tocopherols), Dried Egg Product, Flaxseed (source of Omega 6 Fatty Acids), Natural Flavor, Dehydrated Alfalfa Meal, DL-Methionine, Potatoes, Dried Chicory Root, Pea Fiber, Alfalfa Nutrient Concentrate, Calcium Carbonate, Choline Chloride, Dicalcium Phosphate, Salt, preserved with Mixed Tocopherols, Sweet Potatoes, Carrots, Potassium Chloride, Zinc Amino Acid Chelate, Zinc Sulfate, Vegetable Juice for color, Ferrous Sulfate, Vitamin E Supplement, Iron Amino Acid Chelate, Blueberries, Cranberries, Barley Grass, Parsley, Turmeric, Dried Kelp, Yucca Schidigera Extract, Niacin (Vitamin B3), Calcium Pantothenate (Vitamin B5), L-Carnitine, L-Ascorbyl-2-Polyphosphate (source of Vitamin C), L-Lysine, Copper Sulfate, Biotin (Vitamin B7), Vitamin A Supplement, Copper Amino Acid Chelate, Manganese Sulfate, Taurine, Manganese Amino Acid Chelate, Thiamine Mononitrate (Vitamin B1), Riboflavin (Vitamin B2), Vitamin D3 Supplement, Vitamin B12 Supplement, Pyridoxine Hydrochloride (Vitamin B6), Calcium Iodate, Dried Yeast, Dried Enterococcus faecium fermentation product, Dried Lactobacillus acidophilus fermentation product, Dried Aspergillus niger fermentation extract, Dried Trichoderma longibrachiatum fermentation extract, Dried Bacillus subtilis fermentation extract, Folic Acid (Vitamin B9), Sodium Selenite, Oil of Rosemary.

Guaranteed Analysis

Crude Protein 34.0% min

Crude Fat 15.0% min

Crude Fiber 6.0% max

Moisture 10.0% max

Calcium 1.4% min

Phosphorus 0.9% min

Omega 3 Fatty Acids*1.0% min

Omega 6 Fatty Acids* 2.5% min

Glucosamine* 400 mg/kg min

*Not recognized as an essential nutrient by the AAFCO Dog Food Nutrient Profiles.

Feeding Guidelines

  • 15 lbs: ¬Ω to 1 cup.
  • 16 to 25 lbs: 1 to 1 ¬æ cups.
  • 26 to 40 lbs: 1 ¬æ to 2 ¬º cups.
  • 41 to 60 lbs: 2 ¬º to 3 ¬º cups.
  • 61 to 80 lbs: 3 ¬º to 4 cups.
  • 81 to 100 lbs: 4 to 4 ¬æ cups.
  • Over 100 lbs: 4 ¬æ cups.
  • ¬Ω cup for each additional 20 lbs

Pros

As you can see by its incredible ingredients there is a lot to like about Blue Wilderness Salmon. As we saw earlier on in this post-Salmon is a protein-rich source for dogs. With all the extra vitamins and minerals this dog food satisfies all the criteria your dog needs.

Cons

There is not much to NOT like about this dog food besides the price. As you will see with all high-protein dog foods they are more pricey than the normal dog foods.

Why You Should Buy Blue Wilderness Adult Salmon

The Blue Wilderness Adult Salmon has an impressive ingredients list. The DMB is 37.77% and grain-free, the carbohydrates in this food are derived from peas and sweet potatoes. The food is manufactured in the USA which means it has to follow the AAFCO guidelines.

postDescription.postDescription: Eggs are a very important source of nutrients for your puppy. Eggs are also one of the most complete sources of amino acids, the building blocks of protein.

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about your dog's health from physiology basics to specific issues.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Yes, dogs can eat eggs. They contain vitamin A, riboflavin, folate, vitamin B12, iron, selenium, and fatty acids.

Are eggs good for dogs?

Of course, eggs are also a good source of linoleic acid and fat-soluble vitamins like Vitamin A. All of these are wonderful for a dog‚Äôs skin and coat to make it looks shiny and healthy.

Are raw eggs bad for dogs?

This is a controversial discussion among dog owners. Raw feeders argue for raw eggs, the mixed or non-raw feeders argue for cooked eggs.

Fact is eggs can be a source for Salmonella and E.Coli and your puppy can get sick. Some foods lose some of their nutritional value when cooked, but this is not the case with eggs. Better safe than sorry, I say.

Is eggshell nutritious for dogs?

Eggshells contain calcium and phosphorus, so yes eggshell is good for your dog. The shells can also be valuable for dogs who have difficulty eating bones.

Is the cholesterol in eggs bad for dogs?

A positive thing is that you don‚Äôt need to worry about cholesterol in your dog, because cholesterol doesn‚Äôt have the same effect in dogs as it does in humans and dogs don‚Äôt get to the same cholesterol-related diseases as humans do. That means you don‚Äôt need to feed egg whites only.

Can dogs eat an egg a day?

Eggs are not meant to be eaten every day with every meal. A couple of eggs per week are fine, depending on the size of your dog; less for smaller breeds. Make sure you monitor your dog‚Äôs stool in order to see if he tolerates eggs in the first place. If any signs of stomach distress appear stop immediately.

Knowledge Makes You and Your Dog Happy! Furry Canine Team

postDescription.postDescription: Bananas are the perfect snack for humans and treat for your dog. They‚Äôre sweet, provide energy and come in their convenient wrapper.

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about your dog's health from physiology basics to specific issues.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Are Bananas Safe For Dogs?

Yes, bananas are a great treat for your dog, and unlike other fruits, which may have toxic components, bananas, once peeled, are safe to eat.

Keep reading to learn how to prepare the bananas for your dog, as well as to find out what are the benefits of feeding bananas as well as the hazards that might occur if you are careless.

Can Dogs Have Bananas?

Yes, and because of the sweetness of the fruit, dogs generally love it from the get-go.

Are Bananas Good for Dogs?

Bananas have plenty of benefits, so it‚Äôs safe for your dog to eat a banana as long as it‚Äôs in moderation.

Bananas are filled with potassium, vitamin B and C, fiber, copper, and manganese. Potassium keeps the bones strong and blood vessel function well.

Manganese assists with blood pressure levels and works as a calming effect on dogs that tend to get hyperactive.

Vitamine B6 helps fight anemia, vitamin C helps maintain a strong immune system, and the fiber keeps the bowel movements regular.

When are Bananas Bad for Dogs?

Like other fruits, bananas contain natural sugar. Too much sugar can cause weight gain, which can lead to other health issues. So don‚Äôt go bananas with the bananas.

Peeled bananas are best for dogs, but if your dog eats one whole, don‚Äôt worry because banana peels aren‚Äôt toxic, but it has a high fiber content which might lead to an upset stomach.

Eating too much banana can lead to constipation just as it can happen in humans. The potassium found in bananas is not that well-tolerated in dogs in case ingested in large amounts.

If your dog eats too many bananas, monitor it closely and if your dog shows any symptoms such as diarrhea, constipation, vomiting, etc. contact your vet asap.

How to Serve Bananas for Dogs

As mentioned earlier, ask your veterinarian before feeding your dog or puppy any new foods. They can tell you the best serving size based on his age, size and more. To serve your dog a banana, peel it and cut it into an appropriate size and share the treat with your pup.

If your dog doesn‚Äôt seem to like fresh bananas, try them frozen. ‚ÄúFreezing a fruit or vegetable is another way of changing its texture to make it interesting. In an animal‚Äôs eyes, it probably makes it a different kind of treat, since it‚Äôs a different texture and temperature experience,‚Äù says Dempsey. Frozen bananas make for an especially tasty and refreshing treat on hot days.

How many bananas can a dog eat?

When it comes to bananas for dogs and portion size, you shouldn‚Äôt give most dogs a whole banana.

A small dog should not eat more than a few small pieces. The same recommendation goes for puppies. Large and medium breeds can eat half a banana a couple of times per week.

Do It Yourself Banana Recipes for Dogs

Super easy and super fast!

Banana Chips

Cut the bananas in thin slices, place the slices on baking papers and into the oven until crisp.

Mashed Bananas

Mash up some fresh banana and mix it with your dog‚Äôs food or just give it to your dog as a treat. You can even stuff the Kong Toy with mashed bananas - either frozen or unfrozen.

Frozen Slices of Bananas

Slice up bits of bananas, freeze them and give them to your dogs as a treat. Perfect for hot summer days.

Knowledge Makes You and Your Dog Happy! Furry Canine Team

postDescription.postDescription: I will not beat around the apple tree and tell you right up front: yes, dogs can eat apples and in fact, apples are healthy for them.

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about your dog's health from physiology basics to specific issues.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Are Apples Safe For Dogs?

‚ÄúAn apple a day keeps the doctor away!‚Äù a well-known truth among us humans, but can dogs eat apples?

Keep reading to learn how to prepare the apples for your dog, as well as to find out what are the hazards that might occur if you are careless.

Can I feed my dog apples?

Dogs can eat apples. They are a good fruit to include in your dog‚Äôs diet as long as the core and seeds are removed.

Besides being tasty, apples or apple slices are a good source of low protein, high fiber, antioxidants.

Consider different foods that are good for dogs as well, like bananas and carrots to help keep introducing vital vitamins and antioxidants that battle cancer into your dog‚Äôs body.

Are apples good for dogs?

Apples are wonderful alternative crunchy treats for your dog.

Some dogs have a higher food infatuation and apples can be a low-calorie treat for them.

Apples with the skin on are full of plant chemicals (phytonutrients) that are thought to be protective against some types of cancer in humans.

How should you prepare apples for dogs?

If you want your dog to enjoy this healthy snack, please make sure to wash off any wax or pesticides the apples might have been treated with.

Removing the core and deseeding the apples is a must.

Depending on the size of your dog, I recommend cutting the apples up a bit.

How many apples can dogs have?

About 10% of a dog‚Äôs diet should consist of fruits and veggies.

So it depends on the weight of your dog to determine how much represents 10% actually, but you can always start with a couple of slices.

Not all dogs like apples from the get-go, so if you still want to provide this healthy snack you might need to put in some convincing work.

Make sure you start with a sweeter apple and not a sour one.

Also, dogs are best in observing you, so if you eat apples, chances that your dog will also want some are higher.

Can dogs eat applesauce?

Most of the applesauce, juices, pie or any products made out of apples contain added sugars.

So be mindful of this and do not feed your dog extra sugars.

The answer is: if you cook the natural apples and make the sauce without adding sugars, then sure, feed it to your dog.

Otherwise, I recommend not to do it.

Can puppies eat apples?

Yes, puppies can eat apples.

Please supervise puppies when feeding them a new kind of food.

Watch them carefully as they eat a slice or two and then observe if the apple pieces cause any digestive issues.

If not, apples can make a good treat for your puppy.

What Are the Benefits of Dog Eating Apples?

Some senior dogs or dogs must limit the intake of meaty treats due to protein restrictions, or they need to stick to a low-fat diet.

You can replace their treats, as already stated, with apple chunks.

The benefits aren‚Äôt just for seniors or pups with health issues, though.

For your younger and active dogs feeding apples can pose as a welcomed benefit.

Some vets believe that the antioxidants and vitamin C of the apples, help with degenerative conditions like joint disease, and the fiber will contribute to overall gastrointestinal health.

All types of apples contain cyanide in all parts of the plant except the fruit flesh. Cyanide affects the enzymes responsible for oxygen transport and prevents cells from using the oxygen in the bloodstream making fallen apples a dangerous snack for pets.

Signs of cyanide toxicity include dilated pupils, difficulty breathing, bright red gum color, shock, and death.

However, cyanide toxicity is rare in dogs because the whole seeds or pit must be masticated for the cyanide to be released.

Dogs and cats will often develop signs of stomach upset, such as vomiting and diarrhea if they ingest parts of an apple.

Fruit left on the ground to spoil and ferment can also pose a risk for alcohol toxicity if consumed.

Do It Yourself Applesauce Recipe for Dogs

Super easy and super fast!

What you need:

  • Apples (depends on how many apple sauce cubes you‚Äôd like to make)
  • Water
  • Optional banana

How you do it:

  1. Remove core and deseed the apples and cut them into chunks.
  2. Put the apples in a blender and start it adding water as needed to bring the mixture to the consistency of apple juice.
  3. Add the optional banana if you want to mix things up a bit.
  4. Store apple sauce in ice cube trays for a fun, cool treat, or store in freezer bags to thaw and serve at a later date.

Knowledge Makes You and Your Dog Happy! Furry Canines Team
